title: Before 1 January 2020, will the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) vote in favor of granting a waiver petition [GN Docket No. 18-357] to allow for the further deployment of Cellular Vehicle-to-Everything (C-V2X) technology?
preds: Not enough days left. An NPRM was issued by FCC on this matter on Dec 12. Typically the period between an NPRM and an actual vote is approx. 30-60 days.
Dropping a few points to zero because there's only a few weeks left in the year.

Before 1 January 2020, will the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) vote in favor of granting a waiver petition [GN Docket No. 18-357] to allow for the further deployment of Cellular Vehicle-to-Everything (C-V2X) technology? Downshifting and putting it in park for the duration of the year.

Before 1 January 2020, will the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) vote in favor of granting a waiver petition [GN Docket No. 18-357] to allow for the further deployment of Cellular Vehicle-to-Everything (C-V2X) technology? The days are getting shorter.
Based on global trends, smart cities, and 5G technology the technology will be passed if the legislation doesn’t already exist.
Dropping for passage of time and anticipating the glacial pace of decision making.
Downshifting, because the terrain is steep and there are so many obstacles in the way.
5G technology is not well developed in the USA. There are other developments needed before.
Not enough energy being expended in this space as DC has frozen in place.
Due to the trump administration’s recent attack on fuel economy in California.
Shifting my forecast based on time and reading the recent Bloomberg piece that cafebedouin pointed out in his recent post.

This article is obviously by a partisan in this discussion, but the bottom line is that the FCC isn't going to rush to make a decision in favor of a different communication standard when they want to co-opt this spectrum for Wi-Fi.  "Although many in Washington expressed support for the chairman’s “fresh look,” Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao did not want to have this conversation and requested the agency to postpone the rulemaking. Acquiescing to Washington politics, the day after his announcement, the chairman pulled the item. Another spectrum turf war involving government agencies was engaged." [1] https://news.bloomberglaw.com/tech-and-telecom-law/insight-elaine-chao-needs-to-better-prioritize-dots-spectrum-fights

It would be surprising if not.
This is a technology to observe and to intervene the traffic behavior of every vehicle on the road.
Great opportunity for the government...

the mobile industry will surpress with anything greatfull in these year, https://www.digitaltrends.com, have seen us littel new things, in this way the car and the phone will be one, in these line FCC would say yes, making allways it is  safe,

I agree with cafebedouin to a certain degree about timing.. The slowness of government can be an issue at times. But, I think the C-V2X is a promising technology and may have enough interested fans that it may get that waiver.

Bottom line: This question is low probability. Pai is starting a rule-making process and appears to be favoring opening up the spectrum beyond the automotive industry. There is next to no chance that the FCC is going to undermine the rule-making process by granting this waiver before the rule-making process is complete.  If you review what the rule-making process entails from the FCC website, it is clear this is going to take us outside the time window.[1] They have to come up with a rule. They have to publish a notice in the Federal Register. They need to receive comments for at least 30 days. They need to allocate time for replies. Then, they need to adopt a final rule. Then, this has to go through a peer-review process. Etc. Not going to happen in the time period. Dropping down to 2%. "In a Twitter post, [Ajit Pai] said the band had been 'largely fallow for two decades,' adding: 'It's time to launch a comprehensive review of the future of this band, make a sober assessment of the facts, and then make a timely decision on the best way forward.'[2] Pai could "initiate rule-making as soon as next month." But, Pai is in the pocket of the telecommunications industry, which wants this spectrum for itself, i.e.: "Citing slow progress on talking cars, other industries have been pressuring the FCC to open that part of the spectrum for them to use. The Internet & Television Association has called the 5.9 GHz band 'the future of Wi-Fi,' saying it's a critical tool to end Wi-Fi bottlenecks."[2] On the other hand, "The [Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers] contends NHTSA must complete a third testing phase to see if sharing the spectrum would even be safe. 'You can't have, call it low latency, where the signal isn't going fast enough because people are sharing it when you're in a car on a highway,' Bergquist said. 'We actually want the ability to use the spectrum and have confidence in it for autos. And we can't really speak to the idea of sharing it yet because the testing hasn't been done. If they could do the testing, and we all feel confident, that's terrific. We could share it if the testing says we could, but we just need to be sure that the spectrum is going to be safe.'[2] [1] https://www.fcc.gov/about-fcc/rulemaking-process
[2] https://www.autonews.com/mobility-report-newsletter/states-call-preserving-talking-car-spectrum
Initial impression:  the key to this question is will they have a vote

From what I am understanding, a section of band was set aside for the auto industry and they basically did nothing with it for the past several years. The auto industry now wants a different section of band which is more powerful, however there are probably other more immediate and practical uses for it than using it for auto industry, such as relieving wifi congestion. The 5.9ghz band could be segmented and allow for both uses as well as opening up 6.0ghz. 
I think they will grant the waiver, but maybe not before Jan 01, but it there are several filings coming in this month, so...I'm not sure.

The current geopolitical situation with the China-US trade wars has overemphasized the role of 5G infrastructure for future technological competitiviness, the importance of US developments in 5G in general and the leadership in adopting the use of 5G. While the fact is that the C-V2X technology is not mature enough for real deployment yet (actually for 2+ yrs), FCC will face huge political pressure to open the potential for the option to drive also the C-V2X applications.

Well, read about this and researched it. And based on that work I am no closer to having a good answer or understanding of how the FCC will decide. However, in my experience the safest thing to bet on is always stasis so here we are.
Hat tip to @cafebedouin for an excellent analysis. Since this is viewed as a technology enabler I'll up the odds.

I understand this issue only sketchily despite a briefing from my much smarter engineer son-in-law, but in the current FCC environment anything is a shoo-in if it is opposed by consumers, librarians, the Open Technology Institute, and an outfit that says it favours public knowledge.    My opinion in this matter should be thoroughly disregarded, though, as I am probably being unduly influenced by reality.

My sense is that rather than grant this particular petition, the FCC is going to rewrite the rule, probably in a way that doesn't dedicate spectrum to a particular technology. If they do that, then the petition for a rule waiver will be made moot. "On May 14, 2019, Federal Communications Commission (FCC) Chairman Ajit Pai announced plans to open a rule-making to take a "fresh look" at the 5850-5925 megahertz (MHz) (5.9 gigahertz (GHz)) spectrum band. Initial reports suggested that the FCC would take the issue up in June, but the 5.9 GHz rule-making was not included on the tentative agenda for the commission's June open meeting. Chairman Pai delayed the rule-making at the request of U.S. Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao. The FCC has not provided a timeline for the rule-making, but we expect release of the rule-making sometime this summer."[1] "In this new proceeding, the FCC will consider whether and how to allow sharing in the band between DSRC, gigabit Wi-Fi, and C-V2X technologies. Chairman Pai outlined a wide range of potential outcomes for the new rule-making. As examples, the FCC could:     Maintain the current allocation for DSRC(this outcome seems unlikely because the chairman has already revealed his skepticism about this approach, given the history and outlook for DSRC).
    Allocate the band for exclusive use for C-V2X technology.
    Allocate the band for exclusive use by automotive communications technology generally.
    Allocate the band exclusively for unlicensed uses such as gigabit Wi-Fi.
    Permit sharing between unlicensed uses and automotive safety and other communications in the lower 45 MHz of the band, and permit exclusive use for V2V technologies in the upper 30 MHz of the band.
    Permit exclusive use for unlicensed technologies in the lower 45 MHZ of the band and exclusive use for automotive safety and other communications in the upper 30 MHZ of the band."[2] "“We predict that the FCC will grant the 5GAA's waiver request to allow the deployment of C-V2X in the 5.9 GHz band,” SNS said in response to questions via email. “This will give automakers and other stakeholders the opportunity to evaluate and compare the benefits and performance of both technologies in real-world environments, and consequently help the U.S. Government to appropriately decide which V2X technology is the best path forward − we expect to see a mandate in the early 2020s.”[3] [1] https://www.internationallawoffice.com/Newsletters/Tech-Data-Telecoms-Media/USA/Hogan-Lovells/Update-on-FCC-59GHz-band-rulemaking-proceeding
[2] https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=bd720b14-03d2-4173-9adc-3abb5fd56806
[3] https://www.fiercewireless.com/wireless/sns-analysts-predict-5gaa-will-get-waiver-request-for-c-v2x-5-9-ghz-band
